definition: term in TCM describing the progress of disease as an opposition between vital energy 正氣|正气[zheng4 qi4] and pathogeny 邪氣|邪气[xie2 qi4]
first month of the lunar year
straight/upright/proper/main/principal/to correct/to rectify/exactly/just (at that time)/right (in that place)/(math.) positive
old variant of 邪[xie2]
demonic/iniquitous/nefarious/evil/unhealthy influences that cause disease (Chinese medicine)/(coll.) strange/abnormal
each other/one another/mutually/fret on the neck of a pipa 琵琶[pi2 pa5] (a fret on the soundboard is called a 品[pin3])
surname Xiang
appearance/portrait/picture/government minister/(physics) phase/(literary) to appraise (esp. by scrutinizing physical features)/to read sb's fortune (by physiognomy, palmistry etc)
to strive for/to vie for/to argue or debate/deficient or lacking (dialect)/how or what (literary)
pathogeny (cause of disease) in TCM/as opposed to vital energy 正氣|正气[zheng4 qi4]
superficial syndrome/illness that has not attacked the vital organs of the human body
half outside, half inside/half interior, half exterior
interpretation of the cause/onset and process of an illness/pathogenesis
inner organs
name of disease in TCM
pathogenic influence (TCM)
excess of yang 陽|阳[yang2] in TCM
(TCM) six excesses causing illness, namely: excessive wind 風|风[feng1], cold 寒[han2], heat 暑[shu3], damp 濕|湿[shi1], dryness 燥[zao4], fire 火[huo3]
one of the channels of TCM
pattern-syndrome identification based on the eight principles (TCM)
collapse of 氣|气[qi4] (TCM)
blocked or painful urination, constipation and vomiting (Chinese medicine)
(in Chinese medicine) stasis (of blood or other fluids)
stagnation of 氣|气[qi4] (TCM)
